At 17:02 14/01/2005, you wrote:


>--- Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...> wrote:
>(about symettry)
><snip>
>
>My suggestion is that a symettry detecting network
>might be evolved whose only function is to reduce many
>inputs to few inputs by detecting symettry.  The
>outputs of this ANN would be the inputs to the main
>ANN that is being evolved.
>
>For example, consider a board game played on a
>rectangular board of NxN squares.  The initial ANN
>receives all the inputs but maps them into a set of
>outputs that is equivalent to a rotation of the board
>so that most of the pieces are in the lower left
>corner.  This pre-processing does not have to be done
>by an ANN, but it could be.  The net effect would be
>as if the player viewed the board from various
>positions until he found the one with the pieces
>arranged most toward the lower left.  This greatly
>reduces the variety of configurations that must be
>considered, although they are still considerable.
>This might allow tic-tac-toe to be solved by
>neuroevolution.
>
>I hope I have not been too laconic; I will expand if
>asked.

Hi,
         Let's call it "admirably succinct" rather than laconic.  I get 
exactly what you mean.  I have considered this approach in the past, in 
fact that may even have been when we discussed it before.

         This is what I think of as the Mapping -> Processing -> Demapping 
approach, e.g. an outer subsystem (ANN or other) examines the data, decides 
on an orientation, rotates the data to use that orientation and passes the 
result to the inner subsystem.  The inner does its magic and then passes 
the results back to the outer.  The outer then has to remove the mapping to 
restore "world coordinates", before the answer will make sense to the 
output layer.

         There are two problems with this approach:

A) Demapping.  Obviously if we simply provide the outer subsystem then we 
can guarantee that mapping is the inverse of demapping.  However, if we 
wish to evolve them then selecting them to do that (without applying a 
separate and very specific selection pressure just to this subsystem) is 
very improbable in the face of mutation (remember that the inner system 
cannot operate at all unless the outer is working).  Similarly, we would 
like it to be free to evolve different mappings whilst retaining the 
inverse relationship but that is equally unlikely.

B) Multipliciy of viewpoint.  Given a chess board, exploitation of the 
symmetry doesn't just mean picking a single location and transforming the 
view into it.  Rather, the need is to consider the board under multiple 
transforms and find the one that enables the inner subsystem to return the 
most positive result.  You can view this in two ways (both of which 
probably happen in nature), first, that the inner system feeds back to the 
outer saying "now change the transform to" -- this is essentially the 
roving eye approach.  Second, we can imagine the outer system providing 
multiple transformations of the board and multiple copies of the inner 
system being used to analyze them in parallel.  This is what I call an 
"omnipresent eye" approach.  The advantages of an omnipresent eye are that 
(i) it looks further afield than a roving eye and does not rely on there 
being a path across the board to the region of interest, and (ii) that 
since multiple views of the board are processed simultaneously, data from 
different views can be used in the same calculation (either passing it to 
other views "how dangerous is my neighbour's view?"; or analyzing it in an 
overview subsystem "which view is most confident?")

         Both these limitations illustrate what I am wondering 
about.  Because, although we can fairly easily see some situations under 
which they can be overcome.  We can also see how difficult they would be 
under other conditions.  e.g.

1) In a "custom" system where we have some evolving components, but 
hand-coded systems for other parts, then we could easily set up the 
hand-coded portion so that multiple viewpoints were processed and/or data 
mapped on input is correspondingly demapped on output.

2) In a system where everything evolved, if we were processing only a 
single problem, then it would be very difficult for the system to evolve a 
[network] where mapping and demapping were kept compatible 
_by_the_process_of_evolution_ (e.g. relying on, when mapping mutates, that 
demapping should mutate in the complementary manner).

3) BUT, a system which had evolved (over a far longer period) to handle a 
variety of "symmetric" problems, would/could have developed a general 
purpose map/demap system (a MaDem -- like a MoDem).  Such a system is 
related to the idea of a routing system (e.g. because remapping a 
chess-board is equavalent to rerouting the contents of one square to 
another square).  And a routing system would also be required in order to 
apply the madem system to more than one other system.  Such a system would 
automatically keep mapping and demapping in synchrony, because it would be 
built to *understand* them as two sides of the same coin.  It would be 
soft-configurable with a mapping and loading the mapping would also define 
the corresponding demapping.

--

         So what I am getting at is an interest in 3 which is deeply linked 
to ideas of modularity (and thus probably requiring indirect representation).

         I'm interested in (1) and part of the document I'm currently 
working on is a specification for a system which can do some aspects of it.

         I'm interested in any confirmation/commentary that my analysis 
that (2) forms a "hard" problem for (short term) evolution and hence 
implies the existence of (3) in natural thinkers.

         And I'm especially interested in any information or ideas about 
whether you agree there's an implication that natural thinkers implement 
some sort of systems akin to (3), what sort of level they might be 
implemented at (e.g. is a "router" a 10, 10,000 or 10,000,000 neurone 
structure), what sort of neural structures might be able to do it, and 
whether it can be done with the sort of artificial neurones that we use at 
the moment, or whether some new properties are required.

         Ian Badcoe
